CCR Anchor 6: Acquire and use accurately a range of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when encountering a word or phrase important
to comprehension or expression.

99EA8F6ED4A9494A946159732D3EE388.description: Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., synonyms, antonyms, homographs) to better understand each of the words.

FECB1D76979F4B7CA37CE0F7D6982093.description: Recognize and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and proverbs.

7D08299AF5324FCE9E4875CC388D1248.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

B63C5154078748A68C005DAAACEF0029.description: CCR Anchor 5: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

A33D1D3C852B468C86967F504949057F.description:
Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries,
glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation and determine or clarify the precise meaning of key words and phrases.

204DA4A9C766467E8EA5BC00EC7A19E3.description: Use common, grade- appropriate Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., telegraph, autograph, photograph, photosynthesis).

867B10777EF046FE9293121267AD76DE.description: Use context (e.g., definitions, examples, restatements, cause/effect relationships and comparisons in text) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.

4739BF2B371A473AB94314EDD927F4BB.description: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

94E6B22630DA4BF9B555826C90861C4C.description:

and consulting general and specialized reference materials, as appropriate.

9981D3B3276B4EEF94BBFE5C50E8B937.description: Expand, combine, and reduce sentences for meaning, reader/listener interest, and style.

C43EB47CBA524887A68C03C3DB2472E3.description: Differentiate between contexts that call for formal English (e.g., presenting ideas) and situations where informal discourse is appropriate (e.g., small- group discussion).

1843B05AFFCC4FACA57C4CFFD78A0AFC.description: Choose words and phrases to convey ideas precisely.

D89B6EAC2F364F5AB5A302569F6CA761.description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

711B657EFA42491A9F5FB385454CE1D8.description: CCR Anchor 3: Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

3B45BB70E73F4719808A50415CA16D8B.description: Spell grade-appropriate words correctly, consulting references as needed.

B7384F30D82141F7A8676555312AAB53.description: Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics to indicate titles of works.

0BFCBB47E8D74508A970A5D97942D607.description: Use a comma to set off the words yes and no (e.g., Yes, thank you), to set off a tag question from the rest of the sentence (e.g., Itâs true, isnât it?), and to indicate direct address (e.g., Is that you, Steve?).

2142380532634F2EB7DC16676D696075.description: Use commas and quotation marks to mark direct speech and quotations from a text.

721045EC41264958944A457CB8779E2E.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

3E2490E089024A69BA1597BE7FE8A124.description: CCR Anchor 2: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

E1A77332E2FE4C8697F9C594FD3F2DA7.description: Correctly use frequently confused words (e.g., to, too, two; there, their).

91997EB895D7414C84D449A4CD0F741E.description: Order adjectives within sentences according to conventional patterns (e.g., a small red bag rather than a red small bag).

413F35FE983D4B93BE7D4F36229EB0C1.description: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.

89B58A3B693C42C19B18DA49EAE90551.description: Use verb tense to convey various times, sequences, states, and conditions.

31EDB5EDE81546AF8FE302168CA082F1.description: Use modal auxiliaries (e.g., can, may, must) to convey various conditions.

F3F2019E94B745EF851A998F1A4D8202.description: Form and use the progressive (e.g., I was walking; I am walking; I will be walking) verb tenses.

A42EB2D0E99A439B8D50336294AF99CF.description: Use relative pronouns (who, whose, whom, which, that) and relative adverbs (where, when, why).

1FCBFD6F2F814C04A764B9BCEF26A3D2.description: Explain the function of conjunctions, prepositions, and interjections in general and their function in particular sentences.

912A68D5E2244F6CAA43E3C76C777283.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

0B3E22595A7349CCA30035AC4C434396.description: CCR Anchor 1: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

5B090E2F82074C51AE04EDD3861208C2.description: Differentiate between contexts that call for formal English (e.g., presenting ideas) and situations where informal discourse is appropriate (e.g., small-group discussion); use formal English when appropriate to task and situation. (See Language standards 1 and 3.)

EE29A1F23D6A4803B340990CCA2A4DC7.description: CCR Anchor 6: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and communicative tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate.

503D6C8B63D0400D8A233CF12A6461C6.description: Include multimedia components (e.g., graphics, sound) and visual displays in presentations when appropriate to enhance the development of main ideas or themes.

BBC4E95DE4034A028886187C9889F024.description: CCR Anchor 5: Make strategic use of digital media and visual displays of data to express information and enhance understanding of presentations.

668846DFE41248EAA91EB3F894FB0DB4.description: Report on a topic or text or present an opinion, sequencing ideas logically and using appropriate facts and relevant, descriptive details to support main ideas or themes; speak clearly at an understandable pace.

F425D10D941E42ABA249AF5A0A7E5B3C.description: CCR Anchor 4: Present information, findings, and supporting evidence such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning and the organization, development, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

5D1E918AFA7B481899ADE311C3EEBB7E.description: Summarize the points a speaker makes and explain how each claim is supported by reasons and evidence.

B8D011F96C244715BD9DB36CD45CBD8C.description: CCR Anchor 3: Evaluate a speakerâs point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric.

1C5757BED0A94E0C96FCEAA85288492E.description: Summarize a written text read aloud or information presented in diverse media and formats, including visually, quantitatively, and orally.

C13255608A2943F59542D79FA5ECC89C.description: Paraphrase portions of a text read aloud or information presented in diverse media and formats, including visually, quantitatively, and orally.

ECA1353E253343BEA285C1AB1C399579.description: CCR Anchor 2: Integrate and evaluate information presented in diverse media and formats, including visually, quantitatively, and orally.

2A93B94B1E974D7F87471B7DE6370C38.description: Review the key ideas expressed and draw conclusions in light of information and knowledge gained from the discussions.

4AB64502973E425598E3E2A213C3C8CA.description: Pose and respond to specific questions by making comments that contribute to the discussion and elaborate on the remarks of others.

50D63DD095114B02BA072F6C1540E964.description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussions and carry out assigned roles.

2DA31E43FA444F4C9A28C8C2B1D2019F.description: Come to discussions prepared, having read or studied required material; explicitly draw on that preparation and other information known about the topic to explore ideas under discussion.

A1732722C43D48DDBAB9F5C381408BF4.description: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one- on-one, in groups, and teacher- led) with diverse partners, building on othersâ ideas and expressing their own clearly.

1F12578E5DB4499C82FC101F174879A9.description: Â CCR Anchor 1: Prepare for and participate effectively in a range of conversations and collaborations with diverse partners, building on othersâ ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.

informational text (e.g., âExplain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s)â).

624488FB5F794167A59831637227E900.description: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

52B4A89B20184BBBB4AF16C7EBA403AC.description: CCR Anchor 9: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

8E42272273704F88B14B82AEB3C69DA0.description: Recall relevant information from experiences or gather relevant information from print and digital sources; summarize or paraphrase information in notes and finished work, and provide a list of sources.

DE34238416344557866A00FFD66C022D.description: CCR Anchor 8: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, assess the credibility and accuracy of each source, and integrate the information while avoiding plagiarism.

9CC0DB3B4A314E20BBC27113BC270CDA.description: Conduct short research projects that use several sources to build knowledge through investigation of different aspects of a topic.

1F74C99EC8EF44479BBAD8C544648D5B.description: CCR Anchor 7: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects based on focused questions, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

B8FA2A6A95EA45B2ABF253361DBBC9B6.description: With some guidance and support, use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing as well as to interact and collaborate with others; demonstrate sufficient command of keyboarding skills to type a minimum of one page in a single sitting.Â

FFC9FD5F57784C6BA6A08CFC48EC2D11.description: CCR Anchor 6: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and to interact and collaborate with others.

A104FF0AD0D24893A9D8C6533274516B.description: With guidance and support from peers and others, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach. (Editing for conventions should demonstrate command of Language standards 1â3 at this level.)

BFE9EAB8C784403BA866EF0CB2C56440.description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development and organization are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

E3562B62822F4E4BAE1640BACD6F0B2C.description: CCR Anchor 4: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

F94277B0F84E45DFB07EF1FC74E9213E.description: (Note: Studentsâ narrative skills continue to grow in these levels as students work to incorporate narrative elements effectively into their arguments and informative/explanatory texts.)

CCR Anchor 3: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details and well-structured event
 
 
sequences.

C789C949C35E4DE58E13B07ADC9D0892.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

C554D884903B4B8D94A179BDC9242402.description: Link ideas within categories of information using words and phrases (e.g., another, for example, also, because).

4F47095A95B344DC930DBE04662C8937.description: Develop the topic with facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples related to the topic.

D331295B53DF4F5EA39DC5741F9EE56E.description:
Introduce a topic clearly and group related
information in paragraphs and sections; include formatting (e.g., headings), illustrations, and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.

C3A4388206644EFAB08C3093284F2D55.description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.

9BA5F7321E334CE99BC3E55560F3689E.description:
CCR Anchor 2: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection,
 
 
organization, and analysis of content.

B7BB23BC1BC0465FAC314FD5F5633A7F.description: Provide a concluding statement or section related to the opinion presented. (W.5.1)

4887C615CCA64CDA90022615DE2DCF61.description: Link opinion and reasons using words, phrases, and clauses (e.g., consequently, specifically).

527951FA3B92403E995B1B01DC8D8BFC.description: Provide logically ordered reasons that are supported by facts and details.

0F4C4BD9770F49B2B0027024079ED055.description: Introduce a topic or text clearly, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure in which ideas are logically grouped to support the writerâs purpose.

C57FF48D36FF4726A6CB507A676671F1.description: Write opinion pieces on topics or texts, supporting a point of view with reasons and information.

35F5A8DE8F644F20ABE9368F8A0D624A.description: CCR Anchor 1: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.

D0705D266AAF4E42B75638767E9D297B.description: CCR Anchor 10: Read and comprehend complex literary and informational texts independently and proficiently.

C704A3272FFA4F76A7056F953592C069.description: Integrate information from several texts on the same topic in order to write or speak about the subject knowledgeably.

A3D1FB332FBD451BBA8548AC8A0FE25C.description: CCR Anchor 9: Analyze how two or more texts address similar themes or topics in order to build knowledge or to compare the approaches the authors take.

0E08A59EC0434D84975DB8D004441F9B.description: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).

DA1860EEF45D4226BE89073836DA7C7D.description:
CCR Anchor 8: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, including the validity of the reasoning as well as the relevance and sufficiency of
  
the evidence.

A226BDEEBC0349C59A253E61839F3522.description: Draw on information from multiple print or digital sources, demonstrating the ability to locate an answer to a question quickly or to solve a problem efficiently.

0D80D6E2138643CC91E6E1EE564869AA.description: Interpret information presented visually, orally, or quantitatively (e.g., in charts, graphs, diagrams, time lines, animations, or interactive elements on Web pages) and explain how the information contributes to an understanding of the text in which it appears.

E16C16878BD64AA9AF39211F2E47D28D.description: CCR Anchor 7: Integrate and evaluate content presented in diverse media and formats, including visually and quantitatively, as well as in words.

1840355D759A4B5FA72E47DA64E53839.description: Describe how a narratorâs or speakerâs point of view influences how events are described.

7A2BE371D493465094B0AE420856A34D.description: Analyze multiple accounts of the same event or topic, noting important similarities and differences in the point of view they represent.

F178F7CC760047078915C4E087F64889.description: CCR Anchor 6: Assess how point of view or purpose shapes the content and style of a text.

02397A21D29F46C1AB866EDDB2BED881.description: Compare and contrast the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in two or more texts.

05452E8C8D14412692B23962BB26F8DC.description: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.

E8A9C8A09DBB44DD8ED819145D537BBC.description: CCR Anchor 5: Analyze the structure of texts, including how specific sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text (e.g., a section, chapter, scene, or stanza) relate to each other and the whole.

B92B9D38B8274AE4BACEA8B5FE6E021F.description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.

AC63273A37A04D5E8887E95DEC78BCA2.description: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain- specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a topic or subject area.

71E255C012CF415B965078BC2C95B356.description: CCR Anchor 4: Interpret words and phrases as they are used in a text, including determining technical, connotative, and figurative meanings, and analyze how specific word choices shape meaning or tone.

92D45214467445508C79021DA13ED187.description: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.

D8F1734D66694CDC95620EB5A2DF06C4.description: CCR Anchor 3: Analyze how and why individuals, events, and ideas develop and interact over the course of a text.

38219C5B04914E68B184B07D86B19BE1.description: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.

E4F9D3FEABF5454A8ACE43BF5C672805.description: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.

E4DB655912E54C33806B440D21C31C0C.description: CCR Anchor 2: Determine central ideas or themes of a text and analyze their development; summarize the key supporting details and ideas.

48D2C6FFB85C4956B011AD7E423AF8E7.description: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.

ADD8C6B465A045AAB75DBE471F006198.description: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.

3BF7FB316F6C43E891F00FA2B131CE02.description: Â CCR Anchor 1: Read closely to determine what the text says explicitly and to make logical inferences from it; cite specific textual evidence when writing or speaking to support conclusions drawn from the text.
